Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
I honestly don't understand why there are so many people panning this film. Did they watch the trailer and expect a different thing? This film is great. Here are a couple of reasons why I liked it:


- The film comes with surprises. In addition to downsizing and the environment, it explores other themes you don't expect at first.
- It values scientific accuracy. I wouldn't say it's 100% accurate because it's impossible, but unlike many sci-fi blockbusters, it tries to be consistent and realistic. The entire process by which downsizing was invented and the micro-communities formed is carefully explained and seems pretty okay to me.
- Characters are from several different nationalities. The protagonist is American, the inventor is Norwegian, the neighbor is Serbian, and the activist is Vietnamese. It also takes place partly in Norway. I like the cosmopolitan approach in lieu of excessive Americanism.
- One of the themes it explores is how people can act unexpectedly sometimes. In my opinion, the ending teaches us to look at small things in our lives instead of big ones (what a double entendre!)


This film has a unique feel. It's different but interesting. Perhaps the reason people disliked it is because they're too used to the usual.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
I watched this and thought it was pretty cool, a new concept (kind of, bit like the borrowers) it had a funny tone, likeable characters, etc and a enjoyable plot. I seen that it had bad reviews but seen the stars in it and I thought "it can't be that bad" and it wasn't. I don't know if it's just me, but I think critics are too damn harsh nowadays, everyone wants to be like chris stuckmann or the nostalgia critic or something because that type of media's popular. It's not a perfect film, sure, but it wasn't terrible, it was pretty creative and unique if you ask me. 

There are a lot of films I like that get absolutely trashed, in fact the vast majority of films are considered terrible and only artsy ones get praised. I admit cinema has gone down hill, especially with horror but christ people, not every films that bad...

Comment:
If the 'downsizing' happnes at a cellular level, that means all the cells, organells and indeed the molcules within them are also 'downsized'. Those 'downsized' people would not be able to exist in the same world as us, the oxygen would be too' big' as well as the water and any food at the molcular level.

The only way it would work would be for them to be enclosed in a hermetically sealed, self contained environment. Any supplies would have to be 'downsized' and delivered through something like an airlock.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment: Downsizing is an intelligent and, by American standards, subtle cinematic science-fiction social satire about the individual’s problem of securing sufficient wealth to comfortably sustain their lives in a secure cosmopolitan community for the duration of their lifespan. Downsizing was not well-received by the majority of the viewing public because it is a film about ideas, thus requiring thinking for its enjoyment, as opposed to being a cinematic delivery vehicle for emotive sensations and jolting stimuli to provide passive unthinking viewers with 135 minutes of thrilling distraction. The “lesson” in the screenplay of Downsizing, which was delivered in a clear sedately-paced and understated way (which I like), is that the solution for achieving fulfilling individual lives in peaceful and comforting societies is for the people of such would-be societies to take care of one another: popular humanitarian socialism. This idea is captured visually so simply in the last moments of Downsizing that it remains invisible to the majority of the viewing public. [From my review of Downsizing, at my blog manuelgarciajr(dot)com]

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
**Wow! I just watched this movie and let me say, I didn't think I wanted to watched a depressed Matt Damon mope around making small talk and feeling sorry for himself for 2 and a half hours while doing nothing of interest or significance whatsoever. I was right. I didn't. **

This was complete trash. I am being 100% serious I've never seen a worse movie in my life. It's certainly a comedy but not in the way you think. The only "comedic" thing about this movie is the fact that an entire production team created this movie and not a single one of them shook their head and spoke up to say "Nope. Nope not doing it. This... isn't a movie is is actually garbage and I'd rather feed orphaned children into a wood chipper than be an actor / producer / director / script writer for this movie." Not a single person said that. They all just stood in their places with their poker faces on knowing full well this movie will go down in history as the worst thing humanity has created. It's mind-blowingly awful.

There is no plot. The movie just follows Matt Damon around as he undertakes one depressing adventure after the other. First him and his wife have no money and are concerned with how they're going to get by, then his wife leaves him alone with no money and 2 inches tall in a city by himself, then he meets another woman but she rejects him, then he works a low wage job as tech support, then he meets another woman, then she takes advantage of him and makes him do stuff for him, then he accidentally breaks her prosthetic foot, then to make it up to her he is basically her slave and does her work and gives her the money, then he flees the country to get away from her but she comes with, then he realizes he's somehow in love with her (awww) but decides to leave anyway cus he wants to live in some vault for the rest of his life, then he changes his mind because it's too long of a walk, then he goes and lives in the slums where everyone is in makeshift plywood houses and starving and the movie ends at him looking at an old man. He just looks at an old man who was of no significance to the movie whatsoever. In fact, nothing was significant because the movie was literally nothing.

Very misleading trailer.

I like deep films just as much as the next guy, even the directors past work like Sideways or The Descendants. But this film was about the most average/below average bore fest I've seen in a while. Don't get me wrong you'll like the first 45 minutes, although after its just all down hill.

The film basically turns into this thing where you don't even remember they're small anymore, you do ofcourse but it really has almost zero relevance, it's more a film, marketed to look like a really interesting concept which it is, but that's just one layer to make the film easily marketable, the real film, Is about people and emotions & finding your place in the world, the small things count, all that typical shit.

Main characters, or seemingly main characters played by notable actors, just dissappear and never show up again, characters are 1 dimensional, the one women you're supposed to like in the film "whilst I've gotta agree, well acted at times" was very unlikeable for alot of it, and her accent was almost used in a parody kind of way, plus I'm sure that Absolute Vodka shot wasn't in the final film btw. 

But they do, do alot to keep you remembering they're small, like if you look in the background on one scene you'll see a Polaroid picture on the wall and it looks huge.... Amazing, wow. Its asif the director felt he had to keep doing it cause otherwise the jig was up and we'd find out that being small wasn't the actual premise of the film. I wouldn't be writing this if it was advertised in a way that was honest, but it's not, 80 percent of the trailer, is showing you the good 45 minutes at the start, they barely show the downhill slope it meets in the 2nd and 3rd act.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
The trailer is definitely misleading, making the film seem like it's a full on comedy, when it's actually a dramady. I liked the vision of the film - mostly. The end got a bit confusing, maybe they were packing in too much into a short period of time. But how the film was presented and the overall story I stuck with.

 I particularly enjoyed how the film shows you from the very beginning that this process of downsizing and the company behind it are far from perfect, and we see "larger and larger" examples (pun intended) as the film progresses. Starting with the way the film depicts the process of downsizing hints at the imperfection and absurdity and dangers of these extreme measures. In these YouTube comments, Water Nebula says "It's just slightly unnerving seeing the tiny stacks of human bodies on the trays." Yes, yes it is! Maybe Water Nebula thinks they're the only one to feel that way because the film has such a happy, whimsical song playing during this montage. But I believe that's part of the brilliance of the filmmakers. The filmmakers are making you feel the two sides to the issue of downsizing at the same time; the happiness of the people who support downsizing and are enjoying their new lives - portrayed by the happy music, but also the dark behind the scenes details of it all - as we see in these sterile, white environment where most of the workers seem not to even take it seriously, joking and flirting with each other while on the job.

I mean, isn't that one reason why they knock patients out until they're in the small town? They aren't supposed to see these details. It's like the saying "You want to eat the burger without knowing where it came from." Because the process isn't pretty - and in fact, these people do appear to be on a form of assembly line during the process of downsizing.

While the trailer makes it seem like a person can fix their life by downsizing, the actual film suggests the problems in your personal life CAN'T always be solved by downsizing. Sometimes you have to face who you are as a person, regardless of size.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment: So here's the thing: everyone says that they thought the first half hour/hour was great and the second part was horrible. My opinion: the other way round! The first part, before Paul thinks of getting small, was horrible. So boring and all the time I thought "When will you finally become small!!!". The worst thing of the movie was the changing from tall to small. I couldn't watch. They pulled his teeth!!!!!! This haunted me for the rest of the movie. BUT THEN. Plot twist. Everything changes. And THAT'S what I liked!! Sure, everyone expected a comedy but seriously, don't we have enough stupid, pointless comedies already?? This is the real deal. Something very unexpected happens and that makes the whole movie in my opinion. Sure, Kristen Wiig and Neil P. Harris only have a short appearance but that was good. Give unknown actors more chances! The Vietnamese was great. Amazing. Favourite character, definitely. She was cute, brave, funny and ice cold. I loved her. Watch the movie and build your own opinion. This is mine :)

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment: I'm impressed by the creators of this trailer in how they achieved to make a movie look interesting in the trailer , that is terribly dissapointing and boring when you're actually watching it. I do not think i've ever been so dissapointed by watching a movie based on a trailer that seems interesting. It's not the light hearted or fun sort of movie you'd expect from the trailer, but it's a long, slow story that after the the first 30 minutes , pretty much does not have anything to do anymore with downsizing  concept. After the slow introduction of what downsizing is, the movie has no idea where it wants to go and ends up pretty much going nowhere and ends in an such an anti climax that you're even more dissapointed that you did not walk away when you first noticed it being boring.

Comment:
This is FAAAAAR MORE COMPLICATED then one sentence. "problem is overpopulation".....problem of what?
-Hunger? then you are reducing the wrong people
-Crowded? All the people in the world stacked next to one another would all fit into one city
-Money? We know who holds all the money, and it's not the people being reduced
-Pollution?  There would be more factories needed to produce products for small people

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
I saw the trailer in the theatre a few months ago and I was intrigued. I had the expectation that this was going to go elsewhere. The trailer really leaves a lot out of what the movie is actually about. I was disappointed that the scene depicting a group drinking from a huge vodka bottle ended up not making the final cut. I hap expected he movie to play more on the side of the dichotomy between normal size and miniatures, it wasn’t the case. The movie is more of a character driven piece that uses the miniaturised world as a gimmick to draw you in. Damon’s character is forced to reevaluate his life and find a new purpose. He is a rather depressed character who eventually finds himself through the virtue of altruism. 

I went in to this movie with expectations built up by the trailer that just weren’t delivered. For that reason, I do not recommend seeing it based on the trailer. But if you want to see a movie that has a few good laughs, some sub-par CGI, decent character development driven by a thinly veiled love story, then by all means watch it.  

All said and done, paying to see this movie is no more than a pity fuck for the Hollywood studios.

Comment: This was the worst movie I have ever seen in my life. Only the first 30 minutes feature Kristen Wiig and the shrinking storyline, and all the trailer material comes from the first 30 minutes. After that, it's a bizarre and super boring story about a Vietnamese political prisoner with one foot and human extinction. This movie is over 2 hours and most of it has nothing to do with being small! Most of the movie is boring exposition and nothing actually happens. It's not a comedy, it's not a thriller, it's not a romance - it's nothing. Do not see this movie! Everyone in my group wanted to leave halfway through.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment: Here’s what actually happens in this movie (I just watched it): Matt Damon gets downsized but his wife chickens out at the last minute. He lives in the tiny mansion for a few months and then she divorces him. He moves into an apartment below Kristoff Waltz living above him as a weird party loving drug czar. Then he meets this Vietnamese chick (like, nail salon Vietnamese) who is a house cleaner because she lost a leg while escaping Vietnam. Then the chick gets Matt all hyped up on helping the poor people who live outside the nicer parts of the tiny community. Then Matt and the chick go with Kristoff to the original tiny colony in Norway. On the way the chick and Matt hook up after he massages her leg nub (no, I’m not making this up). It turns out the original tiny colony is now a weird cult that is going to live underground because they heard that the world is going to end in like 200 years so they have to get out now. Matt wants to go with them but chickens out because he loves the chick. Then Matt goes back to help the tiny poor people for the rest of his life while loving the chick. The End. It was such a horrible movie, you guys.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment: Wouldn’t recommend seeing. The trailer only shows footage from like the first 25 minutes of the movie. The rest is completely different, political, and there’s like no plot. Well there is but the structure is really weird. The director focused a lot on little details that had really nothing to do with the plot and then just left really big gaping holes of details that made the movie relatively confusing. I feel as though the director had these big aspirations for how this movie was supposed to be but probably had too many, leading to you leaving the theater confused and questioning what the hell you just watched. Idk, just my opinion.

Comment:
Silly, but I will suspend common sense for a moment and imagine bullshit like this was possible. 

It would cost more keeping these wannabee elves alive than what the environment would  get back from mouse sized pipsqueaks not squandering the resources.

Imagine the cost in creating artificial environments, and having to monitor them to keep snakes spiders, rodents, insects and your pet cat from getting inside and wiping them out. 

We are not meant to be pixie size, pests would suddenly become predators of the lil folk. 

Anyway, seems like a fun movie so why be a killjoy.

The only thing I liked is Christoph Waltz - he is just great in his role ( as always ). But thats it. It has some funny parts, the longer the movie goes, the more are you asking yourself what the heck is it about...the story on the beginning is interessting, but than it gets very weird.The little/big people effects are well made ( but this is no big deal today), but when the little people are on a little boat cruising on a real lake, the real waves are not big for them etc. Ist just weird.  In my opinoin, because of the chaotic and not logic and loooong story / script, it is a very bad movie !  And, the movie comes to theatres in december, but it is NOT a kids movie !

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
The movie seems lighthearted, so, they are not going to deal with the implications I'm thinking of.

-What about technology? They pretty much do make computers as small as possible already. What do the tiny people do for phones? TVs, computers? They are just shrinking people, not things. If the tiny people can make their own tech to scale, then.... that could be applied to make exponentially more powerful tech for the big people. Right? Making intricate computer components could be a cottage industry of tiny town.

-Natural disasters. There are extremely few places that do not have them to some extent. blizzards, fires, earth quakes. Even a minor rain shower could be the scale equivalent to a major hurricane.
Forget about any weather, a lone raccoon could fuck that place up. Where is tiny town? It would pretty much have to be in a building somewhere; someone tending to them like an ant farm.

-$50K=$12.5M in tiny town, as the lady says. It makes sense in the way that your using less land and resources proportionately.  
Thinking of GIJoe sized people; how many of them with their own little beds could sleep in just your room? even if you have a small room, at least 20....comfortably, with patricians and personal space.
How many of them would it take to finish a $1 fast food burger? maybe 5 if they were really pigging out like, eating contest level.
So, everyone goes there to be millionaires on little money. Who is working at those 3 cheesecake factories? It would have to be people who were not even cutting a scrape by existence, and, were forced to shrink, and... now earning tiny dollars...
This would mean, if you had debts, and, a negative net worth,the debt would  proportionately increase to match your diminished potential impact through labor.

-They are shrunken irreversibly. Some of these people might have kids. There would be future generations of native small people ; like a separate species of human intelligent tiny creatures ; unless the process renders you sterile, and, that is whole new bag of nuts since, overpopulation/overcrowding is the ultimate drive of this.

You get live a life of comfort providing you sacrifice the ability to reproduce, its all covered up by the novelty of being tiny.

I don't know how the movie will end up, but I'm hoping that it does NOT go horribly wrong. It would be a nice, refreshing change of pace to see a science fiction movie where a new technology/idea is introduced, and then it just works out, in the end.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
Ah yes, the advancement and progressiveness of science creating a physically inferior underclass under the guise of preservation of precious limited resources further strengthened by the false security of the small ones "feeling rich." Too bad once you're that small you've essentially signed away your freedom forever, as you are physically helpless from now on. But hey, you have "millions" of dollars that you can spend... that is, if the big people will allow you to have things. So go to your mini mansion in your little AAA battery powered toy smart car and wait to die so that the giants can inherit the earth. If enough people were this small, the few remaining big ones could do whatever they wanted and eventually quit caring for those little villages, abandoning them and leaving the little ones to fend for themselves against the big bad world. It's natural selection with a little bit of help from science. 

Of course the exact process is impossible. But if the majority of the world could be duped into permanently adopting a certain way of life such as this "for the greater good," the remaining ones with true freedom would then rule and be able to do whatever they want. That's what is unsettling to me. One day people will begin permanently signing away their freedoms because they believe they're doing some good and they'll find themselves inferior and even worse off than they were before, subject to the rule of those who seized power for themselves and their families when they saw the chance.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
More hysterical propaganda. 

Like all animals, human population is limited by available resources, it doesn't just skyrocket exponentially. The First World is not at risk of overpopulation, we are actually facing under-population due to our declining birth rate (an effect of prosperity among the enlightened, unfortunately). It's exclusively the Third World experiencing rampant population growth, and specifically on the back of Western aid--what do you think will happen once those resources inevitably dry up?

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
I don't think the main problem here is bug or animals.It's the people who doesn't shrink.The tiny city is protected by these people and they build a dome to prevent other things to come in.And I doubt that they will make tiny guns.
So what if those people don't want to protect them,and try to rule them all?What can you do to fight them?As about 6 inches high,you can't fight them physically,cause to be honest,a normal can just step on you and crush you into nothing.You can't out run them,within one step they will catch up you and you're dead.Even you drive your tiny car,they can just run to you and stomp on the car with you in it and squashed it like a soda can,and you are also dead.
Even if tiny people has their own tiny military,I can say one normal size marine can take down at least 100 tiny marine.He can just lay down on them and crush them all in to nothing.And your tiny guns won't do any harm to a normal size marine,they can't even penetrate their gear and won't gonna penetrate the sole of boots.
So what about heavy weapons?Sure,that would do some damage,but don't forget the normal size people has that too.They can just launch one missile and your whole city is gone.When you shrunk,you are inferior to all the other people who didn't shrink.
And they give you 240 times money that can only be used in that city.The rich or the powerful just don't care these,cause they are already live a great life.But those who don't have a lot money will consider this,it's easier to live in the tiny city than outside.
So this movie reveal a new era of slavery and that what I thought about this movie.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
How can people be excited about this crap? This makes absolutelly NO sense at all. First: Most catastrophes are not caused by overpopulation, but natural disasters. Even if you make the point of carrying capacity in terms of food becoming a problem, it could be tackled by GMOs easier and better. Second: You CAN NOT just shrink people down like this. The size of nucleons are unalterable, because the ranges of the strong and weak nuclear forces are fundamental constants. Reducing the space between nuclei and electrons is impossible because of electromagnetism. And even packing molecules tighter together wouldn't work, as there'd be biochemical problems. Correct protein folding and therefore enzymes would be rendered impossible. Third: How could they metabolize food and drinks not their own size? Their tiny enzymes wouldn't work on normal-sized molecules. I'd say if you can alter the fundamental universal constants, carrying capacity is no worry any longer, you're basically beyond even a kardashev III civilization by then. 

This isn't even original, as some say. The shrinking trope has been done to death!
And before someone points out this is supposed to be a comedy: Even a comedy needs suspension of disbelief. Also, it may be because I hate Hollywood comedy to the death, but at least for me they're always the same. Clichee-filled crude humor fests with plots of idiocy. And this looks exactly like that.

Title: Downsizing (2017) - Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures
Comment:
I knew that I smelled typical Hollywood left wing propaganda in this trailer.  The fact that it stars Matt Damon was the first giveaway.

In a nutshell, the radical environmental movement hates humanity.  To them, humanity is a cancer that must shrink and eventually be wiped out to appease the earth goddess.  It's sort of a metaphorical sacrifice that we as a species must make to atone for our sins.(burning fossil fuels, driving SUVs and leaving our air conditioners on for too long etc.)

Of course, the left loves this kind of doomsday scenario. It gives them the chance to convince us that the only way to fix them is by further regulating and micromanaging our lives.
